(Low)

(Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetChainStatus()] [Invalid Chain ID] Can passing negative or zero chain IDs bypass validation and return unintended status information, or cause state lookup errors that reveal internal state structure? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetChainStatus()] [Stale Status] If State.SideChainInfo status is not updated atomically with actual chain termination, can this return outdated status allowing operations on terminated chains that should be blocked? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetChainStatus()] [Status Enumeration] Can an attacker enumerate all side chain IDs by systematically querying until Assert fails, revealing the full set of side chains including those that should remain private? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetChainStatus()] [Race Condition] If chain status is queried simultaneously with a status change transaction, can inconsistent status be returned that breaks assumptions in caller logic? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetSideChainHeight()] [Height Rollback] If State.CurrentSideChainHeight can decrease due to chain reorganization or indexing corrections, does this function return rolled-back heights that could invalidate previously verified cross-chain transactions? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetSideChainHeight()] [Uninitialized Height] Can querying a newly created side chain before any blocks are indexed return height = 0, which might be misinterpreted as genesis height vs uninitialized state? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetSideChainHeight()] [Height Overflow] If side chain height grows beyond Int64.MaxValue, can this cause overflow in State.CurrentSideChainHeight storage or return values, breaking height-based validation logic? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetSideChainHeight()] [Terminated Chain Query] Does the function return the last indexed height for terminated chains, potentially allowing use of stale height data in cross-chain operations that should be blocked? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetSideChainHeight()] [Missing Synchronization] If height updates are not atomic with block indexing, can this return heights for which block data is not yet available, causing failures in subsequent merkle proof verification? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainHeight()] [Missing Parent Chain] If called on main chain where State.ParentChainId.Value == 0, does the Assert properly prevent execution, or can this leak information about chain hierarchy? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainHeight()] [Stale Height] If parent chain indexing lags significantly behind actual parent chain progress, does returning stale State.CurrentParentChainHeight enable verification of transactions that are too old and should be rejected? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainHeight()] [Height Validation] Can the returned parent chain height be less than genesis height (< 1) due to uninitialized state, causing integer underflow in caller logic that assumes height > 0? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainHeight()] [Concurrent Updates] If parent chain height is updated during query execution, can race conditions return inconsistent heights that don't match merkle roots stored for that height? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainId()] [Chain ID Spoofing] If State.ParentChainId can be modified by unauthorized parties, can this return a spoofed parent chain ID that redirects cross-chain verification to a malicious chain? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainId()] [Invalid Chain ID] Can the function return negative or invalid chain IDs that pass the != 0 check but break assumptions in crypto operations or chain identification logic? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.CrossChain/CrossChainContract_View.cs] [Function: GetParentChainId()] [Main Chain Detection] Does the function properly distinguish between main chain (no parent) and side chain scenarios, or can calling it on main chain reveal internal state despite the assertion?
